misconceptions.task: Correct pattern (1 star to N stars)
misconceptions.name: Solved the wrong problem / Misinterpreted the requirements
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading a height N and printing a right triangle of asterisks, the student wrote a program that reads three coordinate points and computes the area of a triangle using Heron's formula. There is no logic related to printing a star pattern or handling rows/columns for the required triangle output.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads three points of a triangle and computes its area using Heron's formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single integer height N from the user and print N lines of output where line i contains i asterisks, forming a right triangle pattern (from 1 star on the first line to N stars on the last line), matching the sample run.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinate points instead of a single height N
No loops to control N rows or stars per row
No asterisk ('*') characters printed in the output
Final output is a numeric area, not a star pattern
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or focused on a different exercise about computing triangle area and did not align their solution with the given specification and sample run for printing a right triangle of stars.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and sample run carefully. Start by writing a program that reads one integer N. Then design an outer loop that runs from 1 to N for each row, and an inner loop that prints the correct number of '*' characters on each row followed by a newline, so the output visually matches the required triangle.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to computing triangle area from coordinates and contains no elements of the required star pattern or structure described in the question, indicating a clear mismatch with the assignment.

evidence.note: The program reads three coordinate pairs instead of a single integer height N required for the triangle-of-stars pattern.
All core logic is devoted to computing and printing the area of a triangle, not to printing a right triangle of asterisks.

misconceptions.name: Completely incorrect task implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the area of a triangle using Heron's formula based on three user-provided points (x, y coordinates), instead of implementing the required program to print a right triangle pattern of asterisks based on a user-provided height N. This indicates a complete misinterpretation or substitution of the required problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the assigned task was to calculate the area of a triangle using coordinate geometry and Heron's formula, or they submitted code for a completely different lab exercise.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required printing a textual pattern (a right triangle of asterisks) of a height specified by the user's input (N). It did not involve geometry or coordinate calculations.
symptoms: Code implements Heron's formula.
Program asks for six double inputs (three points).
No loops or printing of '*' characters are present.
No attempt to address the core requirements of Q4 (printing a triangle pattern).
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt, substituting a solution from a different problem, or submitting the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully review the assignment prompt for Q4 (Print a Right Triangle). If this code was intended for a different problem, please rewrite the program specifically to address the pattern printing requirement using nested loops.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student submission has absolutely no code related to the assigned task (Q4: Printing a Right Triangle) and instead provides a complete solution for calculating Triangle Area using Heron's formula, which is a fundamentally different problem.

evidence.note: The entire main method is dedicated to a geometry problem (Heron's Formula) and not the required pattern printing problem.

misconceptions.name: Complete misunderstanding of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has solved an entirely different problem. Instead of reading a single integer N for triangle height, they are reading three coordinate points (x1, y1, x2, y2, x3, y3) to calculate triangle area using Heron's formula.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to calculate the area of a triangle given three coordinate points using Heron's formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading a single integer N from the user and printing a right triangle pattern made of asterisks, where row i contains i asterisks (1 to N rows).
symptoms: Program prompts for three coordinate points instead of a height
Program calculates area using distance formula and Heron's formula
No loop structure to print asterisk patterns
No asterisk output whatsoever
Output is a numeric area value, not a triangle pattern
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this problem with a different assignment about calculating triangle areas from coordinates. Complete misreading or misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem. You need to: 1) Read a single integer N, 2) Use a nested loop structure (outer loop for rows 1 to N, inner loop to print 1 to i asterisks), 3) Print the pattern row by row.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extreme confidence because the submitted code solves a fundamentally different problem. The program structure, logic, and output are completely inconsistent with the requirements. This is not a minor error but a complete misalignment with the assignment.

evidence.note: Program reads three coordinate points instead of reading a single integer height N as required
Program calculates triangle area using Heron's formula instead of printing an asterisk pattern
No loop structures for iterating rows and printing patterns; instead contains a helper method for geometric calculations

misconceptions.task: Correct pattern (1 star to N stars)
misconceptions.name: Solved a different triangle problem instead of printing a star pattern
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the area of a triangle from three coordinate points using Heron's formula, instead of reading a single height N and printing a right triangle pattern of asterisks from 1 to N stars per row.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that this question is asking for a program that reads three points of a triangle and computes its area (likely another assignment question), rather than printing a right triangle pattern of stars based on a height N.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read one integer N representing the height and then use loops to print N rows of asterisks: the first row with 1 star, the second with 2 stars, and so on up to N stars on the last row.
symptoms: Program prompts for three coordinate points instead of a single height N.
No loops are used to print multiple rows or a growing number of asterisks.
The output is a numeric area value, not a star-based right triangle pattern.
The structure and prompts do not mention height or stars at all.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions involving triangles, or focusing on the word 'triangle' and assuming the task was about geometric area rather than pattern printing.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and ignore any other triangle-related questions you may have seen. Start from the required input and output: read a single integer height N, then design an outer loop for rows and an inner loop (or equivalent) to print the correct number of '*' characters per row, from 1 up to N.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program behavior
Separating different assignment questions or tasks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to computing triangle area from three points and does not include any logic related to reading a height N or printing star patterns, which clearly does not match the specified task.

evidence.note: Instead of reading a single integer height N, the code reads three coordinate points (x1, y1), (x2, y2), and (x3, y3), indicating the student is solving a triangle-geometry problem, not the required star-pattern problem.

The core logic computes the area of a triangle via Heron's formula and prints a numeric area, with no loops or star printing, confirming the program solves a different problem than the required right triangle pattern.

misconceptions.name: Did not attempt the requested task/Misinterpretation of requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the area of a triangle using Heron's formula based on three coordinate inputs, completely ignoring the prompt, which required them to read a height N and print an asterisk right triangle pattern. This reflects a fundamental misinterpretation, or substitution, of the assigned programming task (Q4).
misconceptions.student_belief: The intended task for Q4 was to implement a program to calculate the area of a triangle given three points, likely confusing it with a different assignment or a previous exercise.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task explicitly required reading a single integer N (height) and using nested loops to print a right-triangle pattern of asterisks corresponding to that height.
symptoms: Code implements a completely different program functionality (Geometric area calculation)
Input prompts ask for three coordinate pairs, not a single height N
No looping structure or printing of asterisks is present
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely submitted code for an entirely different problem, failing to address the explicit requirements of Q4.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the assignment prompt for Q4, 'Print a Right Triangle', and ensure the implemented code addresses the requirements for input (read height N) and output (print the asterisk pattern).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the requested task (printing a triangle pattern). It attempts to solve a geometry problem (Heron's formula).

evidence.note: The entire main method and subsequent helper method address a geometry problem (Heron's formula) instead of the required looping/pattern printing task.

misconceptions.task: Overall program structure - all rubric tasks
misconceptions.name: Fundamental Problem Misunderstanding
misconceptions.description: The student misunderstood the assignment requirements entirely. The task asks for a pattern-printing program using loops to create a right triangle of asterisks. Instead, the student implemented a mathematical algorithm to calculate the area of a triangle given coordinates using Heron's formula.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is asking them to calculate the area of a triangle given three coordinate points, or they have submitted code from a completely different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment asks to read a single integer N and use nested loops to print N rows where row i contains i asterisks, creating a right triangle pattern.
symptoms: No loops present in the code
No asterisks printed
Program reads coordinates instead of a single integer
Output is numeric (area) rather than a pattern
Input prompts ask for points, not height
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read the assignment requirements and provided solution code intended for a different problem (triangle area calculation using coordinates).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. You need to: (1) Read an integer N, (2) Use an outer loop from 1 to N, (3) Use an inner loop in each iteration to print i asterisks, (4) Move to the next line after each row.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem with different inputs, outputs, and logic. There is no overlap between what was asked (pattern printing) and what was submitted (area calculation).

evidence.note: Student reads three coordinate pairs instead of reading a single height value N as required.
Code calculates triangle area using Heron's formula. No loops or pattern printing. This is completely different from the required triangle pattern output.
No loops at any level. Class name 'TriangleAreaHeron' and method 'distanceBetweenPoints' both indicate this solves a different problem.
